I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  Armenia  International  Airports  (ArIA)  for  the  Zvartnots  Airport  Expansion  Project  (Phase  2). 
The project will finance the construction of a new landside terminal building and the purchase of 
equipment to supplement the existing airside concourse building. It will increase the passenger-
handling capacity of the Zvartnots International Airport (ZIA) to about 3.2 million a year from the 
current  level  of  1.8  million–2.0  million  a  year.  The  project  will  be  the  first  private  sector 
infrastructure  investment  by  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  in  Armenia  or  the  Caucasus 
region.  
 

II. 

BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE 

A. 

Project Identification and Selection 

2. 
Before  the  breakup  of  the  Soviet  Union  in  1991,  ZIA,  which  was  built  in  the  1960s  in 
Yerevan, operated as a domestic airport. All arrivals to and departures from the former Soviet 
Union  took place  through  Moscow.  After  1991,  ZIA  assumed  a  critical  role  for  Armenia  as  the 
most  important  gateway  to  the  country.  However,  from  1991  to  2001,  capital  expenditure  for 
expansion  and  modernization  was  minimal,  despite  the  significant  need  for  upgrading.  Since 
2002,  significant  investments  to  modernize  the  airport  have  been  made,  but  there  remains  a 
critical  need  for  further  upgrading  of  the  passenger  terminal  to  bring  it  up  to  international 
standards  and  to  enable  it  to  cater  to  the  expected  increase  in  aviation  traffic  to  and  from 
Armenia.  The  project  is  the  final  phase  of  the  modernization  and  expansion  of  ZIA.  Upon 
completion of the project, ZIA will relocate all its operations from the old airport terminal to the 
new  facilities,  which  will  increase  passenger  comfort  and  the  speed  of  passenger  processing, 
provide  a  wider  scope  of  commercial  and  aeronautical  services,  and  bring  the  facilities  up  to 
international standards in terms of safety, security and environmental aspects. 
 
B. 

Sector Background 

3. 
Armenia has a population of about 3.2 million and a total area of about 29,800 square 
kilometers.  Given  its  landlocked  location,  civil  aviation  plays  a  crucial  role  in  the  economy. 
Further  underscoring  the  importance  of  this  sector,  Armenia  has  restricted  use  of  its  southern 
border due to extreme climatic conditions. There is a very limited railway system in Armenia and 
the  road  infrastructure  is  in  urgent  need  of  fresh  investment.  As  a  result,  Armenia  is  largely 
dependent on air transportation for cross-border movement of passengers. Additionally, with an 
estimated strength of 7 million, the Armenian diaspora is one of the largest groups of its kind in 
the world and has a marked impact on the travel market, since members of the diaspora have 
strong social and economic ties with the country and frequently travel to it.  
 
4. 
Although this is the first ADB involvement in the civil aviation sector in Armenia, the ADB 
Central  and  West  Asia  Department  has  had  significant  engagement  in  the  transport  sector  in 
Armenia, particularly in roads projects as shown in the table below.

A recent ADB technical report on the transport sector development strategy1 in Armenia 
5. 
underscored the need for development and investments in a number of areas in the transport 
sector  in  general  and  in  airports  and  civil  aviation  in  particular.  The  report  recommended 
strengthening  institutional  capacity,  governance,  and  legislation,  as  well  as  a  tourism-specific 
strategy  to  eliminate  transport  impediments.  For  airports  and  civil  aviation,  the  primary  goal  is 
the  development  of  competitively  priced  air  services  providing  extensive  connections  through 
efficient  airports.  The  report  also  recommended  that  the  strategy  should  include  a  national 
aviation  system  plan  (which  would  address,  among  others,  the  need  for  new  runway  and 
terminal  infrastructure,  the  feasibility  of  reopening  airports,    passenger  demand  assessment, 
and  the  introduction  of  a  new  Armenian  carrier),  and  identify  the  re-equipment  needs  of 
Armenian Air Traffic Services (the state-owned entity responsible for providing air traffic control, 
navigation, and aeronautical information services in the airspace of Armenia).   
 
6. 
The  Armenian  aviation  sector  experienced  significant  structural  changes  after  the 
breakup of the Soviet Union. Until 1991, it was a part of the former Soviet Union's centralized 
economy, and air fares were subsidized. As a result, traffic levels within the former Soviet Union 
were  very  high  and  passenger  traffic  to  and  from  Yerevan  reached  2.5  million  just  before  the 
breakup of the Soviet Union. Following the independence of Armenia, subsidies were withdrawn 
from  air  fares  and  traffic  to  and  from  Yerevan  collapsed  to  just  over  0.5  million  passengers  in 
2000.  However,  growth  in  passenger  traffic  resumed  in  2001  and  currently  stands  at  over  1.4 
million.  
 
Recognizing  the  critical  importance  of  the  aviation  sector,  the  Government  of  Armenia 
7. 
has taken a proactive role in attracting fresh investment. Modernization of ZIA started in 1994, 
with  EBRD  (European  Bank  for  Reconstruction  and  Development)  providing  a  sovereign 
guaranteed loan to the former Zvartnots Airport Company (ZAC), a state-owned airport entity, to 
construct a new air cargo terminal. The cargo terminal was completed in 1999 and provides a 

                                                 
1  ADB. 2008. Transport Sector Development Strategy. Consultant's report. Manila (TA 4973-ARM). 

  

3

 

 

high-quality  facility  suitable  for  any  modern  airport  (it  has  a  capacity  of  60,000–80,000  tons  a 
year, with the possibility of an expansion to 110,000 tons).  Under the terms of the EBRD loan, 
ZAC was obliged to tender for a private sector manager to take over its cargo operations. The 
tendering  process  was  conducted  in  1998,  but  failed  to  elicit  any  meaningful  private  sector 
response. In 2000 the EBRD commissioned an external team of experts from British Aerospace 
(BAe) to review the overall situation.  
 
8. 
The conclusion of the BAe experts was that the most feasible option would be to involve 
a  private  investor  to  run  the  entire  airport  area,  combined  with  additional  development 
opportunities to be provided by the creation of a free trade zone.  They also indicated that, in 
view of the generally difficult economic situation in Armenia, the proposed investment might be 
of  interest  only  to  a  limited  number  of  investors,  most  likely  of  Armenian  origin,  with  a  longer-
term investment perspective. They therefore recommended direct approaches and negotiations 
rather than an open tender for the concession award. In line with the BAe recommendations, in 
December 2001 the government negotiated a concession agreement with Corporacion America, 
an Argentinean company controlled by Eduardo Eurnekian (an Argentinean citizen of Armenian 
descent). In order to implement this concession agreement, ownership of the airport assets was 
transferred from ZAC to full state ownership, after which the airport concession was granted to 
Corporacion America on an exclusive basis for the management of the entire airport operation 
for 30 years. The concession agreement became effective in May 2002. Following the granting 
of  the  concession,  Corporacion  America  transferred  the  concession  rights  to  ArIA,  its  affiliate 
and  a  special  purpose  Armenian  company.  Subsequently  EBRD,  along  with  DEG  (Deutsche 
Investitions-und Entwicklungsgesellchaft), financed phase 1 of the modernization of ZIA.  
 
The concession agreement grants ArIA the right to be the manager and airport authority, 
9. 
and  the  government's  control  over  ArIA's  operations  in  certain  specific  areas  is  regulated  by 
Armenian  legislation.  The  General  Department  of  Civil  Aviation  (GDCA),  an  adjunct  body 
operating  under  the  government,  oversees  the  safety  and  security  aspects  of  the  airport's 
operations. It has the authority to establish terms and restrictions for the use of the airport for 
safety  reasons,  ensure 
International  Civil  Aviation  Organization  (ICAO)  security 
requirements are met, and to carry out inspections and observations for the purpose of ensuring 
compliance  with  the  ICAO  requirements.  The  Ministry  of  Environment  conducts  environmental 
oversight. In addition, the GDCA regulates and supervises the operations of other major players 
in the civil aviation sector: Armavia, the national carrier, and Armenia Air Traffic Services. There 
is,  therefore,  a  significant  concentration  of  power  with  the  GDCA,  which  is  responsible  for 
setting  procedures  and  technical  regulations,  and  is  also  directly  involved  in  the  day-to-day 
operations of these companies. Any future reform process will have to consider the potential of 
reorganizing the GDCA directly under the Ministry of Transport and Communication, and setting 
up an independent regulatory body in its place (footnote 1).  
 
Under  the  concession  agreement,  ArIA  has  the  right  to  propose  adjustments  to 
10. 
aeronautical  tariffs  from  time  to  time,  in  order  to  ensure  that  it  receives  the  stipulated  internal 
rate of return under the concession. Any tariff revision requires approval by the government, as 
determined  by  an 
intergovernmental  committee  comprising  representatives  of  various 
government agencies. The process of approval of aeronautical tariffs is closely coordinated by 
the GDCA.

C. 

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 

1. 

Consistency with Strategy 2020 

The project is consistent with ADB's Strategy 2020 which identifies infrastructure as one 
11. 
of  ADB's  five  core  areas. 2 ADB  will  invest  in  key  civil  aviation  infrastructure  in  Armenia  to 
strengthen  transportation  and  connectivity  between  Armenian  and  other  countries.  Under 
Strategy  2020,  ADB's  infrastructure  operations  will  emphasize  public–private  partnerships  and 
private sector engagement, which is consistent with the project. Under Strategy 2020, regional 
integration  is  one  of  ADB's  three  complementary  strategic  agendas.  The  project  will  directly 
promote regional integration by improving air connectivity between Armenia and other countries. 
 

2. 

Consistency with the Country Strategy 

12. 
The project is in line with ADB's economic report and interim operational strategy 2006–
2009 for Armenia3 as well as ADB's country operations business plan 2008–20104 for Armenia. 
The economic report and interim operational strategy identifies, among others, the promotion of 
the  private  sector  and  enhancement  of  regional  cooperation  as  ADB's  strategic  priorities.  The 
project  is  consistent  with  two  of  the  principles  underlying  the  economic  report  and  interim 
operational strategy: (i) being selective in determining initial operational areas and focusing on 
delivering  swift  results,  and  (ii)  partnering  with  other  development  agencies  to  exploit  the 
institutional  infrastructure.  The  country  operations  business  plan  envisages  transport  and 
communications  interventions,  focusing  on  modernizing  international  transport  corridors  to 
enhance trade and business opportunities. The project is consistent with this focus. The project 
will be completed within 3 years and will provide immediate benefits by improving Armenia's civil 
aviation  infrastructure  and  air  connectivity.  The  project  is  being  financed  as  a  response  to  the 
economic  crisis,  with  ADB  working  in  close  collaboration  with  the  EBRD  and  DEG  to  ensure 
speedy financing and implementation of the project.  
 

III. 

THE PROJECT 

A. 

Project Description 

1. 

The Shareholder, Sponsor, and Borrower  

a. 

Shareholder and Sponsor 

13. 
ArIA  is  currently  100%  owned  by  American  International  Airports  (AIA),  a  Delaware- 
registered  holding  company  created  in  2002  with  the  objective  of  conducting  airport-related 
activities. AIA is the sponsor and operates out of New York and is indirectly owned by Southern 
Cone  Foundation  (SCF),  an  entity  incorporated  in  Liechtenstein.  The  ultimate  owner  of  AIA, 
through SCF, is Eduardo Eurnekian, an Argentinean of Armenian descent, who has substantial 
interests in airport management, agriculture, energy and fuel distribution, pharmaceuticals, real 
estate, beverages and media.

b. 

Borrower 

14. 
ArIA  was  established  in  May  2002  to  implement  the  concession  agreement  signed  by 
the Republic of Armenia and Corporacion America. In 2006, in accordance with a master plan 
agreed  with  the  government  under  the  concession  agreement,  ArIA  began  phase  1 
modernization program for ZIA, which envisaged the construction of a new passenger terminal 
building  to  house  arrivals  and  an  increase  in  the  overall  airport  capacity.    This  phase  was 
completed in May 2007 and was financed by EBRD and DEG. The new arrivals terminal is now 
fully operational.  
 
15. 
Following  completion  of  the  new  terminal,  ArIA  exercised  its  right,  granted  under  the 
existing  concession  agreement,  to  extend  the  concession  to  the  Gyumri  airport,  the  second 
largest airport in Armenia. Gyumri airport is a small airport serving only the Commonwealth of 
Independent States market, but it is of strategic importance as a relief airport for ZIA during the 
winter,  when  dense  fog  in  ZIA  often  forces  it  to  close  for  2  to  3  days  at  a  time.    The  Gyumri 
runway rehabilitation works were completed in early 2008 and ArIA now operates Gyumri jointly 
with ZIA. Following a review of traffic forecasts and an update of the master plan at the end of 
2007, the government and ArIA decided to proceed with the second and final phase of terminal 
development at ZIA. 
 
ArIA  relies  heavily  on  expertise  available  within  the  AIA  group.  AIA  is  committed  to 
16. 
supporting new investments in ZIA through equity infusion. In addition, AIA provides ArIA with 
managerial  support  in  overall  airport  operations,  ground  handling  and  maintenance  activities.  
AIA  also  supports  ArIA  by  formulating  business  plans,  negotiating  with  local  and  government 
bodies, maintaining relationships with public bodies and institutions, providing financial planning 
and developing sources of funding. AIA also acts as ArIA's interface in negotiating with airlines 
and freight operators in order to attract them to Armenia. It supports ArIA with training and by 
providing  qualified  personnel  from  its  pool  of  international  expertise.  AIA  provides  extensive 
support for the administration of commercial and services-related activities in ZIA.  
 

2. 

Project Design 

The  project  envisages  the  construction  of  a  new  landside  terminal  building  and 
17. 
installation of equipment and facilities to supplement the airside concourse that was built during 
phase 1 of the modernization program. This new terminal, which will house separate departure 
and  arrival  halls,  will  replace  the  existing  terminal  (built  during  the  Soviet  era)  and  house  the 
functions previously based there. The design is expected to lead to a simpler and more efficient 
operational layout, allowing for planned growth in the future if needed. Together with the existing 
arrivals and departure building in the airside terminal, the project will provide enhanced levels of 
service  and  comfort  for  passengers  (reducing  walking  distances  and  optimizing  passenger 
circulation  flows).  Upon  completion  of  the  project,  the  passenger  handling  capacity  of  ZIA  is 
expected to increase to 3.2 million per annum from the current 1.8–2.0 million. 

 
18. 
The  new  terminal  building  is  a  two-level  system  separating  arriving  and  departing 
passengers and their respective processing areas. The new check-in hall will be equipped with 
counters fitted with common user terminal equipment technology and self-check in kiosks. The 
check-in  system  will  be  connected  to  a  new  outbound  baggage  system  taking  luggage  to 
carousels in the basement, where security personnel will use customs clearance scanners, new 
X-ray  equipment  and  tomographers  to  analyze  it.    The  project  also  includes  a  new  multilevel 
vehicle parking area in front of the arrival hall. Because Yerevan is located in one of the most 
active  seismic  regions  in  Armenia,  the  proposed  terminal  building  will  be  based  on  the  latest 

 

 6 

 

seismic structural designs. The project design, which forms a part of the overall master plan for 
the development of ZIA, complies with the standards and recommended practices of ICAO and 
the  International  Air  Transport  Association  (IATA).  The  project  will  also  provide  a  strong 
demonstration  of  best  practice  in  the  area  of  energy  management  and  environmentally 
sustainable  design.  It  utilizes  several  elements  of  best  available  techniques  for  energy 
performance of building infrastructure and service equipment.  
  

3. 

Project Outputs and Outcome 

19. 
The  project  will  augment  the  capacity  of  ZIA  from  the  current  level  of  1.8  million–2.0 
million  passengers  a  year  to  about  3.2  million  and  will  streamline  and  modernize  passenger 
handling  and  processing  systems.  When  it  is  completed,  Armenia  will  have  a  modern  airport 
that  meets  world-class  service,  efficiency  and  safety  standards,  and  high  environmental 
standards. The proposed new terminal is expected to be significantly less energy-intensive than 
the  departure  terminal  that  it  will  replace.  Efficiencies  are  expected  in  almost  all  areas  of 
passenger-handling  operations,  including  the  check-in  process,  arrivals  and  baggage  claims, 
security, immigration and customs control. The project has a significant local cost component, 
which will increase the level of activity and employment in the local construction industry during 
the construction phase. Upon completion of the project, the number of jobs at ZIA is expected to 
increase by at least 500 in the areas of ground-handling, duty free operations, and other retail 
activities. 
 
20. 
The  construction  of  a  modern  terminal  will  enhance  passenger  comfort  and  support 
overall growth in civil aviation. The project will support an expected passenger traffic growth of 
3% per annum starting in 2011 (leading to an increase in passenger traffic from the current level 
of  over  1.4  million  to  about  1.7  million  by  2015)  and  corresponding  increases  in  aircraft 
movements.   
 
B. 

Development Impact 

1. 

Contribution to Economic Growth and Poverty Reduction 

Aviation is a key facilitator of economic growth. The project will meet a vital infrastructure 
21. 
need in the aviation sector of Armenia and contribute to economic growth. Aviation is not only a 
major  industry  in  its  own  right  (employing  large  numbers  of  highly  skilled  workers  directly  and 
indirectly),  but  also  is  essential  for  integrating  a  country  into  the  rapidly  globalizing  world 
economy. Aviation generates wealth, jobs, taxes and tourism. For a landlocked country such as 
Armenia, strong and efficient aviation infrastructure is particularly significant. More connections 
to  the  global  air  transport  network  can  boost  productivity  and  economic  growth  by  providing 
better access to markets, enhancing links within and between businesses and providing greater 
access to resources.5  Air transport acts as an economic catalyst by providing a new and faster 
mechanism for distributing goods and services, contributing to growth in existing industries and 
increasing overall economic efficiency.  
 
The project envisages the construction of a state-of-the-art international airport terminal 
22. 
in the capital city of Armenia that will meet high levels of service, safety and security in line with 
international standards. Upon completion, there will be tangible improvements in the operational 
efficiency of the airport, which, in addition to improving passenger comfort and ease of travel, is 

                                                 
5  International Air Transport Association. 2007. Summary of Aviation Economic Benefits – IATA Economics Briefing 

No. 8. Montreal. 

 

  

7

 

 

expected  to  attract  more  airlines  and  encourage  more  frequent  flights.  Armenia's  air 
connectivity,  which  is  currently  one  of  the  worst  in  the  Central  Asia  and  Caucasus  region,  is 
likely  to  get  a  boost  upon  completion  of  the  project.  Demand  for  air  traffic  is  also  likely  to 
increase in line with overall economic growth. In addition, the new airport terminal will provide 
greater opportunities for retail activities and create jobs in various related and ancillary sectors. 
The  greater  economic  activity  resulting  from  increased  connectivity  and  traffic,  as  well  as 
commercial activities, will have an indirect effect on poverty reduction. The project is also in line 
with  the  master  plan  agreed  by  ArIA  and  the  government  and  is  consistent  with  the 
government's development plans for the sector.  
 

2. 

Private Sector Development 

The 2002 privatization of ZIA was a successful privatization effort in a key infrastructure 
23. 
sector. Since then, significant private capital has been invested in its modernization. The project 
will augment further private sector investment in the airport development program by supporting 
the  final  stage  of  its  modernization.  Greater  private  sector  involvement  in  the  airport's 
management will support the government's efforts to bring about efficiency and a high level of 
safety and security at the airport. Given the project's high profile in Armenia's overall economy, 
it  is  expected  to  play  a  catalytic  role  and  encourage  the  government  to  pursue  similar 
privatization  efforts  in  other  areas.  Over  the  last  8  years  of  the  concession,  ArIA  has  drawn 
heavily  upon  its  affiliates  for  technical  expertise  in  aviation  management  and  this  has  been 
gradually  transferred  to  local  employees  and  professionals  (as  can  be  seen  by  ArIA's  
increasing  reliance  on  local  staff  to  run  airport  operations).  Direct  training  and  development 
programs are also provided to local staff by ArIA's affiliates operating in South America. 
 
C. 

Environment and Social Dimensions 

1. 

Environment 

24. 
The potential environmental impacts of the project, as related to its location, construction 
and operation, have been assessed by an initial environmental examination, and were found to 
be insignificant or temporary. Any environmental impacts of the project can be readily mitigated. 
The  project  has  been  classified  as  category  B  for  environment  in  accordance  with  ADB's 
Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009).    The  project  will  meet  the  ICAO  and  European  Aviation 
Safety Agency environmental standards and will upgrade the environmental, health and safety 
standards  of  the  airport.  Various  impact  mitigation  measures  have  been  included  in  the 
environmental management plan, as part of the initial environmental examination (Appendix 2), 
and adopted by ArIA. The proposed terminal is within the premises of the existing airport, and 
will be integrated with it. No aesthetic impact is expected. The impact on groundwater or surface 
water  is  anticipated  to  be  minimal  because  the  groundwater  levels  are  generally  4-8  meters 
deeper than the building's foundation, and no surface water body, including rivers or lakes, will 
be  affected.  During  construction,  dust  is  expected  from  excavation,  transportation  of 
construction  material,  emissions  from  construction  vehicles,  among  others,  but  this  will  be 
mitigated by measures such as periodic water spraying and covering of construction materials. 
When the airport is operational, the only fixed source of pollution will be from the boiler house, 
which  will  run  on  natural  gas.  It  will  meet  the  required  emission  standards  and  will  have  no 
major impact on air quality. The project is expected to lead to additional vehicular and air traffic, 
but increases in air emissions will be negligible because (i) the access roads to the airport have 
ample capacity for additional traffic so there will be no congestion-related air emissions, and (ii) 
increased  air  emissions  from  additional  flights  will  be  offset  by  the  fact  that  the  newer  aircraft 
operating in the airport will have much lower emission levels than those operating now.  

 

 8 

 

 

 
25. 
The major sources of noise during construction will include excavation, transportation of 
materials, and operation of construction equipment, but their impact will be minimized by careful 
planning and scheduling of machinery operations and use of low-noise equipment. There are no 
hospitals or schools near the project site.  An analysis of the current and future noise impacted 
areas indicates that, when the airport is operational, aircraft noise impact will decrease and the 
affected area will be smaller than at present because the aircraft will be significantly quieter than 
those today, particularly the older Russian jets.  In addition, the project requires aircraft to follow 
a noise-abatement procedure that establishes noise-preferable routes to avoid flying over areas 
that are susceptible to noise.  
 
26. 
There  are  no  major  health  and  safety  hazards  anticipated  from  project  implementation 
and  operation.  ArIA  has  developed  an  environmental  management  system  according  to  the 
International  Organization 
for  Standardization  (ISO)  14001  and  a  health  and  safety 
management  system  according  to  the  Occupational  Health  and  Safety  Advisory  Services 
(OHSAS)  18001,  which  is  currently  being  implemented.  The  resettlement  site  to  house  the 
displaced  persons  has  been  examined  for  its  environmental  impacts.  No  significant  negative 
impacts will result from the construction of the new residential buildings, which will be on major 
roads  and  in  an  existing  community  where  adequate  waste  and  waste  water  management 
infrastructure is provided by the government. 
 

2. 

Social Dimensions  

27. 
The  new  terminal  is  being  built  on  vacant  land  owned  and  used  by  ZIA.  Therefore,  no 
land acquisition or involuntary resettlement is required for the project.  However, as part of the 
master  plan  for  the  rehabilitation  of  ZIA,  ArIA  is  required  to  remove  four  residential  buildings 
inside the airport territory, affecting 506 residents. The project has therefore been classified as 
category A for involuntary resettlement in accordance with ADB's Safeguard Policy Statement – 
Safeguards  Requirements  on  Involuntary  Resettlement.  ArIA  has  prepared  a  resettlement 
action plan (RAP) in line with ADB and EBRD's policy requirements. Since 2006, ArIA and the 
government  (through  the  General  Department  of  Civil  Aviation)  have  consulted  with  the 
displaced  persons,  most  of  whom  are  airport  employees.  An  Armenian  translation  of  the 
summary RAP (Appendix 3) was disclosed to displaced persons in September 2009.  As per the 
RAP,  displaced  persons  are  entitled  to  relocate  closer  to  Yerevan  City  to  apartments  that  are 
the same size or larger than their current ones. Moving charges will be shouldered by ArIA and 
free  daily  transportation  from  their  new  residence  to  the  airport  will  be  provided  to  airport 
employees. No loss of income or employment is expected as a result of the relocation. The site 
for the new buildings has already been identified and a preliminary design for the building has 
been  agreed  upon  with  the  displaced  persons.  ArIA  will  be  responsible  for  financing  and 
implementing the relocation process. ArIA has allocated $13 million for the relocation program, 
which  has  been  included  in  the  project  cost.  To  comply  with  ADB's  Public  Communications 
Policy (2005), the RAP will be posted on the ADB website.  There are no indigenous peoples in 
Armenia  and  the  project  does  not  trigger  ADB's  safeguards  requirements  on  indigenous 
peoples.

The development of the aviation sector is key to the development and economic 
growth of Armenia. ZIA is the most important link between Armenia and the rest 
of  the  world  and  is  therefore  of  key  strategic  importance.  Strengthening  and 
modernizing the airport will help to connect Armenia to the rest of the world and 
make  movement  of  passengers  more  efficient,  which  will  lead  to  enhanced 
economic growth. The ADB investment will play an important role in developing a 
sector that has suffered from underinvestment.  

Armenia  has  been  significantly  affected  by  the  global  financial  crisis.  Growth  in 
Armenian GDP declined from 13.8% in 2007 to 6.8% in 2008. During 2009, GDP

banks for the project that were originally envisaged are no longer available. The 
ADB loan will be a timely crisis response and will be critical to bringing in much 
needed  external  investment  and  increasing  the  confidence  of  the  international 
business community. The project also represents an ideal opportunity for ADB to 
partner with EBRD for the first time in a private sector infrastructure project and 
to deepen relations with DEG. 

The  proposed  initiative  is  strongly  aligned  with  Strategy  2020.  The  investment 
focuses on infrastructure development, private sector development, and regional 
integration.  The  project  is  aligned  with  ADB's  economic  report  and  interim 
operational  strategy  (2006–2009)  for  Armenia,  which  identifies  private  sector

Armenia's transport sector and regional integration.

A. 

Description of the Environment 

SUMMARY OF INITIAL ENVIRONMENTAL EXAMINATION 

The project is located within the existing Zvartnots International Airport which lies within 
1. 
the  Ararat  valley  at  an  altitude  of  858  meters  (m)  above  sea  level.  Ararat  mountain  is  to  the 
south and the project area is situated in the Ararat plain, which is defined by the river Araks in 
the southwest and the river Kura in the northwest. The airport is about 12 kilometers (km) from 
the center of Yerevan city. The climate is continental, with hot summers and cold winters. The 
absolute  maximum  temperature  in  summer  is  420C,  with  a  minimum  of  -300C  in  winter.  The 
Ararat valley consists of lower–upper quaternary volcanic tuff and coarse grained debris which 
are  covered  by  contemporary  alluvial  sediments  (clay,  sand,  and  anthropogenic  soils).  The 
Yerevan  area  is  considered  one  of  the  most  active  seismic  areas  in  Armenia.  In  the  20th 
century,  more  than  10  earthquakes  greater  than  M4  magnitude  have  been  registered,  the 
strongest of which was in 1937 with a magnitude of M4.7. There are no designated biodiversity 
sensitive  areas,  such  as  nature  reserves,  wetlands,  or  bird  protection  areas  in  the  immediate 
vicinity of the airport. The nearest surface water course is the River Hrasdan about 1,000 m to 
the east. In Armenia, about 96% of water used for drinking comes from groundwater resources. 
There are wells in the vicinity of the airport in use for irrigation purpose.

Findings and Recommendations 

11. 
An analysis of the baseline environmental conditions indicates that the proposed project, 
including the relocation site, would not have adverse impacts on the environment that cannot be 
mitigated.  The  identified  impacts  are  limited  to  the  construction  phase  and  therefore  are 
temporary  and  small-scale.  Adequate  mitigation  measures are  proposed  for  implementation  in 
the  form  of  an  environmental  management  plan  that  will  be  implemented  during  construction. 
No further environmental assessment is deemed necessary.

SUMMARY RESETTLEMENT ACTION PLAN 

  
1. 
Introduction.  As  part  of  the  master  plan  to  rehabilitate  and  expand  the  operations  of 
Zvartnots International Airport, Armenia International Airports (ArIA) has undertaken construction of 
the new passenger terminal which will replace the old terminal 1 building. The new terminal is being 
built  on  vacant  land  owned  by  Zvartnots  International  Airport.    During  construction  of  the  new 
terminal and as part of the airport master plan, four residential buildings inside the airport territory 
will be removed.   
 
2. 
Scope of involuntary resettlement impacts. The affected residential buildings include two 
identical  medium-rise  multi-dwelling  buildings,  a  four-story  hostel,  and  a  training  center  hostel. 
Apartment  units  are  either  owned  or  occupied  by  current  or  former  airport  employees.  The  asset 
inventory  and  census  of  residents  was  updated  in  2009  and  found  that  506  residents  in  171 
apartment units will be affected. 
 
3. 
Socioeconomic  profile.  The  airport  and  its  various  service  providers  employ  about  3,000 
people.  A  large  percentage  of  the  residents  work  at  the  airport  as  drivers,  mechanics,  customer 
service  employees,  shift  managers  at  check  in  counters,  flight  attendants,  and  pilots.  School-age 
children attend classes at a primary school near the airport or in Yerevan city.   
 
Participation,  consultation,  and  information  disclosure.  Since  2006,  ArIA  and  the 
4. 
government  of  Armenia  (represented  by  the  General  Department  of  Civil  Aviation  [GDCA])  have 
consulted with the building residents, who have been informed about the need to relocate them, the 
location of the proposed resettlement site, and their entitlements. ArIA has elected to proceed on a 
voluntary  basis  and  to  incentivize  residents  to  relocate  by  offering  homes  in  a  better  area. 
Residents  are  willing  to  relocate  provided  that  they  will  be  given  apartments  of  the  same  size  or 
larger  in  Yerevan  city,  moving  charges  are  covered,  and  free  transportation  is  offered  to  airport 
employees.  An  Armenian  translation  of  the  summary  resettlement  action  plan  (RAP)  was  made 
available to affected people in September 2009.  To comply with the Public Communications Policy 
(2005) of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), the RAP will be posted on ADB website.   
 
5. 
Legal framework and entitlements.  Analysis of Armenian laws reveals that there are gaps 
between national requirements and the involuntary resettlement policies of ADB and the European 
Bank for Reconstruction and Resettlement (EBRD).  ArIA has adopted policy principles to address 
these  gaps,  e.g.  providing  replacement  apartment  units  regardless  of  nature  of  ownership  rights.  
The entitlements of affected people are shown in Table A3.

6. 
Relocation to new apartment buildings. The new buildings will be constructed on a plot of 
land  at  Malatya–Sebastia,  Yerevan  city.  The  site  was  selected  as  it  is  closer  than  the  current 
buildings  to  Yerevan  city  and  to  markets,  schools,  government  and  community  facilities,  and 
employment  opportunities.  A  preliminary  design  of  the  replacement  buildings  has  been  prepared 
and is being disclosed to the affected people. Each affected owner of the apartment units and each 
registered  occupant  of  the  hostels  will  be  assisted  by  ArIA  to  register  his  or  her  replacement 
apartment  units  as  per  the  Law  of  the  Republic  of  Armenia  on  Apartment  Building  Management 
(2002).  
 
7. 
Grievance  redress  mechanism.  If  issues,  complaints  or  grievances  arise  about  the 
relocation,  the  ArIA  Maintenance  and  Environmental  Department  will  engage  the  complainants  to 
identify solutions and resolve grievances in a participatory manner. If the issue cannot be resolved 
at this level, it will be elevated to the Grievance and Redress Committee with representation from 
ArIA, the city government of Yerevan represented by the GDCA, and affected people. 
 
Income restoration. No loss of income or employment is expected as a result of relocation. 
8. 
Airport  employees  will  retain  their  positions  and  free  transportation  will  be  given.  Those  who  are 
employed  outside  the  airport  will  be  closer  to  their  jobs  in  the  city  of  Yerevan.  Unemployed 
residents  will  have  a  better  chance  of  getting  jobs  as  the  new  building  is  close  to  employment 
centres. 
 
9. 
relocation process. The GDCA will supervise and monitor the process. 
 
10. 
Implementation  schedule.    ArIA  will  hire  a  contractor  to  build  the  new  building  in 
approximately  2.5  years.  ArIA  will  ensure  that  no  physical  displacement  will  take  place  until  the 
replacement  buildings  have  been  constructed  and  the  individual  apartment  units  are  ready  for 
occupancy.  Construction  will  begin  in  March  2010  and  will  be  completed  in  November  2011.  The 
residents will move directly from their current homes to their new residences by February 2012. AIA 
will assist the residents in the moving process.
